title: 109_s1739
content: SECTION 1. RELEASE OR DETENTION OF A MATERIAL WITNESS. Amendments to Title 18 include the arrest of a material witness if their testimony is deemed crucial in a criminal case or before a Federal grand jury. Amendments to Title 18 allow for the arrest of a material witness if their testimony is essential in a case and they have failed to appear after being served with a summons or subpoena. A judicial officer can waive the summons or subpoena requirement if there is clear evidence that the person is likely to flee or cannot be adequately secured for their appearance. A warrant issued under subsection (a) for a material witness must contain the witness's name or a description for identification, and specify that their testimony is needed in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding. The warrant for a material witness must contain the witness's name or description, specify the need for their testimony in a criminal case or grand jury proceeding, command their arrest, inform them of their right to counsel, and be signed by a judicial officer. The warrant issued for a material witness must be signed by a judicial officer and upon arrest, the officer must show the warrant to the witness. After arresting a material witness, the officer must inform them of the warrant's existence and purpose, providing the warrant upon request. After arresting a material witness, the officer must inform them of the warrant's existence and purpose, providing the warrant upon request. The warrant must be returned to the judicial officer after execution, and any unexecuted warrant can be canceled by a judicial officer at the request of the United States Government attorney. Initial appearance procedures are outlined in subsection (c). After arrest, a material witness must be promptly brought before a judicial officer. The initial appearance can take place in the district of arrest or an adjacent district if feasible. At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant against them and the supporting documents. At the initial appearance, the judicial officer must inform the material witness of the warrant, their right to counsel, allow them to consult with counsel, and decide on release or detention. If the appearance is in a different district, transfer may occur. Upon initial appearance, the judicial officer must inform the material witness of the warrant, their right to counsel, and decide on release or detention. If the appearance is in a different district, transfer may occur. The judicial officer must order the release of a material witness arrested under a warrant on personal recognizance or bond unless there is clear evidence that release will not ensure their appearance. The judicial officer must release a material witness unless there is clear evidence that their appearance cannot be assured. Testimony can be secured by deposition if the witness is unable to comply with release conditions. If there is no reasonable assurance of appearance, the witness may be detained after a hearing. After a hearing, if a judicial officer finds by clear and convincing evidence that no conditions will assure the appearance of a material witness, the witness may be detained for up to 5 days or until their testimony can be secured by deposition or court appearance. Upon motion, detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 5 days or until testimony can be secured by deposition or court appearance. The detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 30 days in a criminal case or 10 days in other cases to secure their testimony before the court or grand jury. The detention of a material witness can be extended for up to 30 days in a criminal case or 10 days in other cases to secure their testimony before the court or grand jury, with a requirement of demonstrating good cause for the extension. "A judicial officer considers the history and characteristics of a material witness when deciding on release or detention. Challenges to the warrant may also be taken into account. A release order must meet specific requirements." "A release order must comply with specific requirements, while a detention order must meet the conditions of section 3142(i) and ensure a material witness is held separately from individuals charged with criminal offenses under the least restrictive conditions possible." The Attorney General must provide an annual report to the Judiciary Committees of the Senate and House of Representatives on the use of this section by the US Government. The report should include the number of warrants sought and granted under subsection (a). The Attorney General's annual report must include the number of warrants sought, granted, and denied under subsection (a), the number of material witnesses arrested but not secured for testimony, and the average detention period for these witnesses. The amendment to Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure requires the court to supervise the detention of defendants awaiting trial and material witnesses to prevent unnecessary detention.
